speaker: MN
transcript: Its intermediates in general, doesn't matter which small molecule we catalyze. So CO2 is like an obvious one, nitrogen is an obvious one. There are obvious problems with that. But we learn so much that, and I'm also a little bit confused honestly, and I apologize for my naivete about the proper definition of negative emission science still. Right? It reminds me a little bit of, you know, green chemistry before 1990 just dealt with the waste that was already being produced rather than preventing waste in the first place. So I'm not completely sure that there is a clear definition. So that's why I, sorry, I'm just trying still to get calibrated here. But like to me, right, if I look at the chemical industry, if you look at fine chemicals, right, the higher you go up in complexity, the more waste you produce. I mean, that translates to a bigger CO2 footprint as well. So, you know, all of a sudden we could be talking about electrochemical approaches to chiral synthesis of like building blocks or more complex molecules. So I don't, you know, I don't want to take the discussion in the wrong direction. I'm just confused about what our focus is. But to finally answer Marcus's question, I was just talking about generating the chemical fuel for the enzyme that does the reaction we don't know how to do it properly. So you spend less energy making NADH if your enzyme gives you the product you want, for example.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: MN explains that negative emission science is similar to pre-1990 green chemistry by focusing on dealing with existing waste rather than preventing it.
annotations.present new idea: MN introduces the idea of using electrochemical approaches for chiral synthesis of building blocks or complex molecules to reduce waste and CO2 footprint.
annotations.ask clarifying question: MN asks for clarification about the focus of their discussion on negative emission science.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: MN supports their point about waste in the chemical industry by stating that higher complexity leads to more waste and a larger CO2 footprint.
annotations.express frustation: MN expresses confusion and apologizes for their naivete about the proper definition of negative emission science.

speaker: KK
transcript: Um, and so I just want to build off an idea that Michael just said. So what I wrote down was more along the lines of what you were mentioning is using electrochemistry more broadly as a synthetic chemistry tool, right? So, you know, making um carbon-carbon bond formation or like doing sort of organic chemistry electrochemically. Um is there an opportunity to um to do that and would that be in terms of like the is that going to is that going to decrease um waste, make those make those reactions more efficient and more um and less expensive carbon or CO2 sense in terms of how much energy goes into um the those uh later stage chemical transformations.

annotations.expand on existing idea: KK expands on MN's idea of using electrochemistry by suggesting its broader application as a synthetic chemistry tool for organic reactions.
annotations.ask clarifying question: KK asks if using electrochemistry as a synthetic tool will decrease waste and make reactions more efficient in terms of energy consumption and CO2 footprint.

speaker: AH
transcript: I I'd be interested in building on that one a little bit. Um so so I think there's two things to think about. Uh the the first one is really like identifying what what the transformations that that make a difference are. So maybe something like the the top 10. So so there was this article maybe 10 years ago about biomass conversion and like what the top 10 platform chemicals are to to get to all the other stuff that we produce. And and so maybe like revisiting that and and sort of saying what are the targets and then which ones are kind of most amenable to to synthesis with renewable routes. And and on that uh on that point, um you know, there's there's two ways to think about it because there's the direct electrochemistry which so so that's more the area I'm involved in. Um but but there's also the argument that if you can produce H2 and CO and a couple building blocks maybe with electrochemistry, then you can kind of just drop those into existing infrastructure and and do a lot of the synthetic chemistry that we already have uh in our industrial processes. And so I I was hoping somebody in here would be like a life cycle analysis kind of big big picture thinker because we I think we have a lot of molecular people here. Um but but curious to get get input and and team with people who you know, have have the expertise to to decide what what the priority chemistries are. You know, once we say this is the reaction to work on, then I think a lot of us have the tool set to to optimize it and develop better materials and things like that, but sometimes choosing the problem is hard.

annotations.expand on existing idea: AH expands on KK's idea of using electrochemistry as a synthetic chemistry tool by suggesting identifying the top 10 most impactful transformations and considering both direct electrochemistry and producing building blocks with electrochemistry.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: AH refers to a 10-year-old article about biomass conversion and platform chemicals to support the idea of identifying key transformations.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: AH explains two ways to think about renewable routes: direct electrochemistry and producing building blocks like H2 and CO with electrochemistry to integrate into existing infrastructure.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: AH expresses the hope that someone with life cycle analysis expertise can provide input and team up to decide priority chemistries.

speaker: ChM
transcript: If if I can build a little bit on what was said, I I think I I think Adam and and Carlos are are right on in terms of like thinking about the scale. Um, you know, I I'm not a life cycle analysis person, but I I I work with people who who are and a lot of the concern with the commodity chemical route is it it's important from a cost perspective and it is negative carbon emissions because if you're not using CO2 generated feed stocks or fossil fuel feed stocks to make those that that's good or you're not using fossil fuels to make them. But the the the amount of those commodity chemicals we make are small compared to uh the big feed stocks like methanol, like CH4, like acetic acid, things like that, which are enormous, enormous, enormous drivers of the uh fine chemical industry. Um so so it's just a matter of making sure the life cycle analysis suggests that it will not only be negative, but that it's the big uh negative emissions. And and I think things like carbon chloride, carbon nitrogen bonds, carbon fluoride bonds, or carbon halogen bonds and even small like C1, C2, carbon carbon coupling bonds are are really um from my very not life cycle analysis uh perspective are the ones that I've heard anecdotally as the big drivers uh in that more so than making the pharmaceutical products, for instance.

annotations.expand on existing idea: ChM expands on AH and CM's ideas by adding considerations about the scale of commodity chemicals and their impact on negative emissions.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: ChM explains the importance of considering scale in negative emissions and clarifies the role of commodity chemicals like methanol, CH4, and acetic acid in the fine chemical industry.

speaker: WS
transcript: Maybe something to add about just um your respective chemistry. Generally, we're going to be using electro chemical approaches to either replace or work in concert with thermochemical approaches. Beyond the chemistry, the mode of operation I think is really important in terms of flexibility and scale. So if you look at, you know, this example of ammonia, if you have steam, methane performing high temperature running 24/7, Haberbash, high temperature 24/7. Um one of the advantages of electro chemistry is that even a part of that can follow the load directly or have some kind of buffer, it can be a flexible way to, you know, use excess grid electricity to store hydrogen and then be able to defeat it at different time scales. And so the modes of operation for those things are not only continuous, uh high temperature and large scale. I think some of the flexibility that we get in electro chemistry is we can scale things down, which isn't always seen as an advantage, but we can scale them down and be flexible. So I think in in terms of the chemistry, there may be certain chemistries like I would think, you know, making hydrogen um as something that can load follow from the grid, take the excess renewable electricity at a given time of the day, store hydrogen, use it somewhere else. That may give us more advantages than just trying to do something directly uh electrochemically, which will be hard to compete one to one with thermochemistry. So the thing I just want to add there is that, you know, the flexibility and the scale of electro chemistry gives us a lot of advantages when we're trying to couple different types of systems together.

annotations.expand on existing idea: WS expands on the discussion of electrochemistry by focusing on its flexible modes of operation and scalability as key advantages.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: WS uses the example of ammonia production and hydrogen storage to illustrate the flexibility and scalability of electrochemical approaches.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: WS explains the concept of electrochemical approaches as methods that can replace or work with thermochemical approaches, highlighting flexibility and scale as important factors.

And that may help later for the techno life cycle analysis too. Um because when you know pinpoint on what scenario we want using those.

speaker: MH
transcript: I guess just to piggy back off that conversation. I think I think it is important um to think about there's two ways to think about what to make. One is the order of magnitude like potential for carbon sequestration. So if you think about that, like going after something like cement and steel, right? Um is really important. Um but can you do it electro can you electrify that process is unknown, right? Um and so there's the order of magnitude approach to deciding what is worth going after. Uh but then there's the the approach of we can do something we know we can engineer something to do that task. Um and so I'm curious uh about this group what they think um like it should drive the research, should be be going after things based on order magnitude um of the the potential for CO2 sequestration or should we be going more after um what we can electrify within the next five years.

speaker: CM
transcript: So, can can I just piggy back off of that a little bit by saying I I you know, I didn't want to come across as throwing cold water on the idea of electrosynthesis and this feeds into a little bit what you're saying. I think figuring out how to do electrosynthetic transformations that are universal to wide varieties of synthetic processes is useful is very useful because you're not targeting a specific molecule but you're target it's methodology. It's basically organic methodology using carbon-free feed stocks. And so it's a big aggregate effect. And I think that's really important um to think about both in the scale and that so so it's complicated because there's some of those processes that could be electrified in the next five years that may not be a giant component individually, but might have a larger continuing uh impact over the next 10 or 15 years as the industry begins to shift away.

transcript: Yeah, if I can just build on that the sort of planting the seed that electrochemistry can be a major synthetic tool um to that can impact a lot of different transformations. And what I've wondered about is how like when you're designing a system to do a particular transformation, how um specific does that material need to be for a particular transformation or can we build um uh electrodes or electrochemical systems that can do many different types of electrochemical transformations given the same um electrochemical systems given the same electrode basically. Right? So might not be like the perfect electrode to be to do one particular transformation perfectly, but it can do many very well. Um and I think that's uh

speaker: WS
transcript: I think information we can get about that looking at at one particular system, I do think we do need this life cycle perspective because no no one system is going to do everything. You know, that everything in the chemical process industry includes multiple steps and an example of where that can be relevant of just having that information is, you know, if you want to do uh CO2 conversion to syngas and make, you know, send send gas to a Fisher trope synthesis plant. Well, if Fisher trope synthesis is going on at like, you know, 50 bar or something, then you can start to question, well, do I want to make my syngas at atmospheric conditions, then pressurize the gas and send it in, which is, you know, several energy penalties. Or if you know the downstream processing is already at high pressure, what if we do our direct electrosynthesis at directly high pressure? And then you so so in that sense, I think getting to that question of what are the ideal conditions we want for our system to understand fundamentals and optimize mechanisms. I think we do need to know more about the up and downstream processes in terms of, you know, what volumes do they need, what again, what flexibility um do they have and and even what conditions they run at because the integration is going to be where where I think electrochemistry will win is if we can integrate with existing processes that are already very, very efficient. You know, can we can we have the same efficiency of one step without the CO2 emissions or even improve efficiency, but I think the integration is going to be essential to knowing what are the conditions to optimize an individual catalyst or electrode.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: WS uses the example of CO2 conversion to syngas and Fisher-Tropsch synthesis to support the need for a life cycle perspective and understanding upstream and downstream processes in electrochemical systems.
annotations.expand_on_existing_idea: WS expands on the prior discussion of electrochemistry as a synthetic tool by emphasizing the importance of system integration and considering the entire chemical process.
annotations.explain_or_define_term_or_concept: WS explains the concept of integrating electrochemical systems with existing chemical processes, highlighting the need to consider operating conditions like pressure and flexibility.
annotations.ask_clarifying_question: WS implicitly asks clarifying questions about the ideal conditions for electrochemical systems by prompting the group to consider factors like volumes, flexibility, and operating conditions of up and downstream processes.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker explains that scientific challenges will be specific and different depending on the type of catalyst used, such as heterogeneous or molecular catalysts.

annotations.express frustation: The speaker expresses frustration at their inability to answer the question posed due to the complexity and specificity of the scientific challenges involved.

speaker: DY
transcript: You mentioned the word controversy a couple of times. You do want to be a little controversial in an event like this. That's how you're pushing, you know, you're pushing the frontier. Jordi, if I can jump into, I've been quiet and I'll reiterate my caveat that I'm I'm the non-scientist in the room here. But I had the same question as I was as I've been listening is tying it back to the negative emissions goal. I've been trying to kind of bucket what I'm hearing into what sound to me like things that would fall into a stricter definition of negative emissions of actually removing, removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere or the ocean that have been emitted previously by some other process versus decarbonizing some existing process or replacing it, replacing an existing process that emits. So that, you know, you that I would put that in kind of the mitigation basket, not the negative emissions basket. So Jordi, I think I may be just saying what you said in a different way, but that's also where my head goes is trying to understand how what what of this discussion is more relevant to kind of reducing future emissions versus having pathways to actually, you know, quote unquote undo emissions and reduce existing greenhouse gas stocks.

annotations.ask clarifying question: DY asks for clarification on how the discussed research relates to negative emissions versus decarbonizing existing processes to better understand the focus of the conversation.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: DY explains their interpretation of negative emissions as removing existing greenhouse gases versus decarbonization which focuses on reducing future emissions.

speaker: CM
transcript: The idea here that getting off the three percent of carbon emissions from ammonia production is not of interest, but cutting off the smaller component of carbon equivalence from CH4 sequestration and conversion is interesting.

annotations.express alternative decision: CM rejects the focus on ammonia production (3% of carbon emissions) and suggests focusing on CH4 sequestration and conversion, which has a smaller carbon footprint but is scientifically interesting.

speaker: JC
transcript: I would bounce that to Daniel. What do you think from the perspective of the funding? Is this, because you're basically, you're the signalers of what's interesting in some avenues.

annotations.encourage particpatioin: Jordi is inviting Daniel to share his perspective on the discussion and the relevance of funding certain research avenues.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Jordi is asking for Daniel's input on how funding considerations influence the perceived importance of different research directions related to negative emissions.

speaker: DY
transcript: Yeah. Yes, sure. Well, this puts me in a scary position to be telling you all what's important here. I, and I'm sorry, I don't remember your name, but the gentleman who made the comment that it sounds like scientific progress in this area could equally, or at least in theory, could be applied to both mitigation and negative emissions. And if that's true, then that's just a win-win. So that maybe these distinctions don't really help. But here's as a funder in this space, I'll share, I'll share my thoughts, which is if you saw the chart that we see a lot that in the keynote that comes from the 2017 UNEP report that's showing, showing the projections decades out of, you know, even with a very aggressive pathway for emissions reduction, right? You still need this massive wedge of negative emissions of the removal of previously emitted greenhouse gases out of the atmosphere or the oceans somehow at a scale of 10 or 20 gigatons a year by mid or late century. That's what focuses my, my attention as a funder on those, specifically the negative emissions technologies that aren't getting funded and aren't getting developed that we wish we'd have been developing the core science for 10 years ago, right? Because we can't wait till 2050 to all of a sudden just, you know, reach into the closet and pull out 10 gigaton a year scaled, you know, everything. You know, like we're, we're behind there. So that's why negative emissions for me is the focus is that, you know, by comparison, the efforts to reduce our, our emissions are getting more funding and more attention, whether it's through, you know, the electrification of everything or, you know, all of this stuff that we're talking about. It's not to say that I don't think it's important. It's more just that if we don't, if we don't acknowledge that actual negative emissions is the plug that's making these climate models work in 2050 and beyond, and we don't have actual scalable negative emissions technologies, then, then the climate math breaks. So, um, it's not at all to diminish the importance of, you know, if there was a breakthrough in core science that was applicable to both mitigation and to negative emissions, that's, that's a no-brainer win-win. But, but I'll stop here because I see the time's running out. I hope that explains it. That's why funders like us are so attracted to negative emissions because it's, it's those tools don't seem to be there yet, and we're going to need them.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Daniel clarifies the funder's perspective on negative emissions technologies and their importance in achieving climate goals, differentiating them from mitigation efforts.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Daniel references the 2017 UNEP report and its projections to highlight the need for substantial negative emissions by mid-century to meet climate targets.
annotations.express enthusiasm: Daniel expresses excitement about the potential for breakthroughs in core science applicable to both mitigation and negative emissions.

speaker: JC
transcript: So the way that I hear this is that there's an opportunity gap that nobody seems to be filling. And that, that's the same that I heard when I was pitched this meeting is that there seems to be an opportunity gap.

annotations.present new idea: Jordi introduces the concept of an "opportunity gap" in negative emissions technologies, noting that this gap is the reason the meeting was convened.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: Jordi defines what he understands as the central theme of the discussion so far: an "opportunity gap" in developing negative emissions technologies.

speaker: AH
transcript: Just as a clarifying question, in the models there, they look at like realistic and aggressive levels of reduction, but, but they're not, I mean, what, what's the scenario where you could actually take emissions to near zero? Like if, you know, basically freeze where we're at right now. Like I, I guess what I'm, what I'm asking is, you know, what, what fraction of what we're putting out right now is being put into the model as the aggressive target for reducing emission versus what, what, you know, in the most ideal future reality could, could be, you know, accounted for by, by completely cutting out emissions. Because the, the reason I, I wonder about the, the focus of, of the discussion here and, and kind of the, the conference as a whole is if, if the question is we really need the, you know, negative emission is the only answer, then the beyond CO2 conversation we're having here is kind of moot, and we should all kind of just circle back to CO2.

annotations.ask clarifying question: AH asks for clarification on the scenarios used in the models, specifically regarding the possibility of near-zero emissions and the fraction of current emissions considered in aggressive reduction targets.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: AH explains the concept of negative emissions as the only solution and questions the relevance of discussing beyond CO2 if that is the case.

speaker: CaM
transcript: Well, I mean, other greenhouse gases are, you know, a big piece of the radiative forcing equation. So CO2 is the biggest one, but methane's big, and other ones are big too. So, I mean, the direct air capture of methane is, is a pet topic of ours, you know, who's looking into that.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: CaM explains that other greenhouse gases besides CO2, such as methane, contribute significantly to radiative forcing, justifying the importance of exploring methane capture.

speaker: DY
transcript: But, but I'll briefly answer, try to answer your question to the extent I can, which is, you know, those projections, you know, they don't have emissions flatlining. They have emissions obviously going down. We're somewhere in the 40-ish gigatons a year globally of CO2, and I think it's 50 if you do CO2 equivalent and include, include non-CO2 greenhouse gases. And, you know, I mean, from visual memory, even the aggressive cases have, you know, positive emissions going down from the 40s into maybe like 10 gigatons a year or five or something, that residual that you just can't, you know, you'll never be able to get rid of. And then it's the actual negative emissions that are the offset to that at the scale of 10 gigatons a year in 2050 or something like that, depending on the model, depending on the temperature.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: Daniel provides specific data points from climate models to support his argument about the need for negative emissions technologies, referencing 40-ish gigatons of CO2 annually and projections of 10 or 5 gigatons a year in aggressive reduction scenarios.
annotations.ask_clarifying_question: Daniel is attempting to answer Adam's question about emission reduction scenarios in climate models, specifically addressing the possibility of near-zero emissions and its impact on the discussion's focus.
annotations.explain_or_define_term_or_concept: Daniel clarifies the distinction between positive emissions (regular emissions going down) and negative emissions (removal of previously emitted gases) to explain how climate models project future scenarios.
